docs.snippet: LEAD: RECENTLY I found myself fondling a dollar bill of such limp antiquity that it called the entire concept of cash into question. This tattered, pale greenback had been in circulation since the late 60's, but were it not for its privileged isol...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: RECENTLY I found myself fondling a dollar bill of such limp antiquity that it called the entire concept of cash into question. This tattered, pale greenback had been in circulation since the late 60's, but were it not for its privileged isolation on the island of Cuba, it would long ago have been incinerated.

headline.main: Crumbling Cuba Still Loves to Rumba

docs.snippet: The cruise ship Queen Mary 2 docked in the southern Spanish port of Málaga, en route for Gibraltar, which Spain ceded to Britain in 1713 and has been trying to recover since. The impending visit to Gibraltar via Spain comes just four days after t...
docs.lead_paragraph: The cruise ship Queen Mary 2 docked in the southern Spanish port of Málaga, en route for Gibraltar, which Spain ceded to Britain in 1713 and has been trying to recover since. The impending visit to Gibraltar via Spain comes just four days after the Spanish government said it was lifting a ban on cruise ships moving between Gibraltar and Spanish ports. The three-year-old policy had caused tension between London and Madrid.
docs.abstract: Queen Mary 2 docks in Malaga, Spain, en route for Gibraltar just four days after Spain lifts three-year-ban on cruise ships moving between British-held Gibraltar and Spanish ports (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Europe: Gibraltar: Spain Lifts Ban On Cruise Ships

docs.snippet: IT was the middle of March in the mountain town of Lienz, Austria, and the temperature was nearly 70 degrees. Even though this capital of East Tyrol is 2,200 feet above sea level, the sun shines down on it most of the  year, separating it from the...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT was the middle of March in the mountain town of Lienz, Austria, and the temperature was nearly 70 degrees. Even though this capital of East Tyrol is 2,200 feet above sea level, the sun shines down on it most of the year, separating it from the more famous, crowded and cloudy resorts on the north side of the Alps. I was in the arcaded sidewalk cafe of the Hotel Garni Eck, drinking a melange, an Austrian version of cafe con leche, and watching the passers-by in this city of 15,000 residents crisscross the city's main square, the Hauptplatz. Many of the older strollers wore the traditional green, feathered Tyrolean hat. Behind them were the white-trimmed windows, powder gray walls and onion domes of the town hall, housed in Liebburg Castle. The castle was once the home of the Baron of Wolkenstein-Rodenegg, who bought the Lordship of Lienz from Emperor Maximilian in the 16th century. To the south and west, the romantic Dolomites, a line of unforgettably jagged peaks, towered over the city. An almost vertical wall of stone more than 8,000 feet high, these rocky pinnacles achieve a haunting rose at sunset.
docs.abstract: Bill O'Sullivan article on Lienz, sunny Austrian mountain town that was an important stop on overland European trade routes during the middle ages; photos; map (M)

docs.snippet: As winter loosens its grip on London, pedestrians return to the South Bank of the Thames....
docs.lead_paragraph: Why Go Now One sign that winter has finally begun to loosen its tenacious grip on London is the stream of pedestrians returning to the South Bank of the Thames. At the first hint of good weather, friends meet for an after-work drink at one of the increasing number of Thames-side pubs, sitting on outdoor benches and turning their faces toward the late-afternoon sun as they down a pint of lager. Art lovers stroll among the galleries in Bankside and Southwark. Tourists make the requisite pilgrimage across the famed Millennium Bridge -- now that it has overcome its (literally) shaky beginnings five years ago -- to the imposing site of Tate Modern, which dominates the river like the set of a Fritz Lang movie.
docs.abstract: Jennifer Conlin travel article on lodging, restaurants, tourist attractions and shopping along London's Thames River; photos; map (M)

headline.main: Along the Thames, Bidding Winter Farewell

docs.snippet: The hermetic Himalayan kingdom, a Shangri-La of astonishing beauty, opens its doors a little wider....
docs.lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, Penny George ''couldn't have located Bhutan on a map.'' But after hearing friends rave about their trip to the tiny Buddhist kingdom tucked in the Himalayas, Ms. George, president of a foundation that promotes holistic medicine, was hooked. This fall, she and her husband made the long journey from their home in Minneapolis to Bhutan's sole airport, then spent seven days on a guided tour, trekking into virgin forests, tiptoeing into temples and passing through villages where men and women still go about in traditional dress. ''Bhutan has bubbled up in the collective consciousness,'' said Ms. George. ''I just felt like I had to go.'' Move over, Cambodia. Bhutan is the new must-see destination in southern Asia. With Tibet in the grip of Communist China and Nepal deemed unsafe by the United States State Department, this peaceful nation half the size of Indiana is emerging as a big draw, attracting those in search of a spiritual journey, a hiking adventure -- or just a chance to experience a place before the rest of the world gets there. The number of visitors to Bhutan, as small as a few thousand not long ago, increased to 9,000 last year, a third of them Americans. Travel agents report an upswing in interest in Bhutan, and tour operators like Abercrombie & Kent are adding both trekking and cultural trips to their rosters. ''Among those who have been everywhere, seen everything,'' said Rok Klancnik of the World Tourism Organization, a United Nations agency based in Madrid, ''interest in Bhutan is growing.''
docs.abstract: Janet Margolies travel article on why Bhutan, with one main road and only five months of prime travel weather, has become new must-see destination in southern Asia; photos; map (L)

headline.main: Why Is Everyone Going to Bhutan?

docs.snippet: MOSHE BRILLIANT is on the staff of The Times bureau in Jerusalem. BY MOSHE BRILLIANT   T he Western Wall of the Temple Mount in Jerusalem is Judaism's most sacred shrine. Your guide may tell you that the Wall, or at least its foundations, are reli...
docs.lead_paragraph: MOSHE BRILLIANT is on the staff of The Times bureau in Jerusalem. BY MOSHE BRILLIANT T he Western Wall of the Temple Mount in Jerusalem is Judaism's most sacred shrine. Your guide may tell you that the Wall, or at least its foundations, are relics of King Solomon's Temple, destroyed by the Babylonians in 587 B.C. In fact, the Wall was erected by Herod the Great in the closing years of the first century B.C. This in no way detracts from its sanctity, however. For 2,000 years, the Wall has been the focal point of Jewish prayer. It became known as the Wailing Wall because of the tears shed there (Israelis refer to it officially as the Western Wall). The chinks between the massive ashlars are stuffed with strips of paper inscribed with prayers.
